Description: Mould-made pottery lamp with a circular body, a narrow rounded shoulder, and a voluted nozzle with relief patterns between the volutes; the rear volute-spines join below the nozzle, and are surmounted by rosettes. The discus is decorated with concentric mouldings. On each side is a lug-handle; at the rear is an applied cylindrical handle (mainly missing) which probably curved forward over the body and terminated in an animal's head. The lamp stands on a multiple base-ring with a central boss. Brown, micaceous clay. Plaster mould.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: See also 'Bonner Jahrbücker' cxviii, 1909, p.381, fig. 5.1. A close copy of bronze lamps like Walters, H.B., 1914. ‘Catalogue of Greek and Roman Lamps in the British Museum’. London : British Museum Publications, 65. Found with the lamp-holder 1888.0920.35b.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (Q1965)
Petrie 1889a / Hawara, Biahmu and Arsinoe (p.10, pl.XV, 15)
Kelley 1976 / The pottery of ancient Egypt : Dynasty I to Roman times (pl.102, 2, 15)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1997 22 Oct-1998 30 Apr, Italy, Rome, Fondaione Memmo, Ancient Faces
